content: 6 messages were moved here from #Is there code for X? > Characterisation of connectedness using continuous maps by Junyan Xu.

As a data point, here is an excerpt from Conway's A Course in Functional Analysis, Appendix A.2. He did not introduce the ≤ notation but his use of "larger" of "smaller" is consistent with the subset order. You're welcome to provide your references!
image.png

Thanks, this excerpt is indeed a very nice argument in favor of mathlib's convention, both through the way he explicitly mentions there are several coexisting convention and the way he very carefully uses the reversed inclusion symbol ⊇\supseteq⊇

Thanks for your input, but note that he didn't mention coexisting notations, but only coexisting nomenclature. In mathlib ≥ represents ge which means `greater than or equal to", and I see no difference between "greater" and "larger", so Conway's use of the word "larger" is consistent with the subset order but not the current default, the superset order. I wouldn't exclude the possibility that some authors use ≤ (or another notation of the same directionality) to mean ⊇ in the context of topologies, so you're welcome to provide another data point!

I'm tired of this discussion and I have actual work to do. I've never seen ≤ used in this context so there is no trouble at all, and our convention simply works better for the way we do topology in mathlib, which is very suitable for formalization and does not exist on paper as far as we know. Maybe we could redefine topological_space X to be a function from X to filter X satisfying the appropriate axiom so that you find the ordering more natural but I don't have time for this. The ordering we use are already fully consistent from filter to uniform spaces through topologies. I really don't see the point of inverting one order relation in the middle of this chain.

From a categorical perspective there's no choice to be made, the forgetful fibration Top -> Set has fibers that are posets, and the least (resp. greatest) elements of these posets are the discrete (resp. indiscrete) topologies.
So mathlib has bought into the categorical perspective, where the existence of arrows X -> Y is another way of saying X <= Y.

Patrick Massot said:

Junyan Xu said:

I find this a bit unintuitive BTW that t₁ ≤ t₂ means t₂ ⊆ t₁; it's contrary to [the usual notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_topologies#Definition.

No, it isn't. The usual notation is never t₁ ≤ t₂. Where do you see that on this wikipedia page? This page very clearly says that people can't decide what is the order relation and use both.

Because of @Christian Merten's PR today I realized the order on GrothendieckTopology is contrary to the order on TopologicalSpace.
The former was added by @Bhavik Mehta in mathlib3 and has been there for four years. Should we make them consistent or not? If yes which convention should we choose? I'd guess we'd follow TopologicalSpace because much less GrothendieckTopology has been developed compared to it.

I would say that the inconsistency is fine here - as far as I know, the convention on Grothendieck topologies is the one I added (which is why I added it!), and I don't think this is a sufficiently good reason to change mathlib's ordering on TopologicalSpace.

Regarding the order on Grothendieck topologies, one has to be careful that the game of sites has a few contravariant functors built in. In the topological case, the underlying category is that of open subsets of the space, so functors between those categories and continuous maps between those spaces run into different directions. But the game of toposes has restored the order used for spaces.

The convention in logic is that False is Bot and True is Top, and P -> Q means P <= Q. We can't change that. With topological spaces t1 <= t2 means (X,t1) -> (X,t2) is continuous so it's the same convention.
What I meant is that the natural functor between O(X,t1)\mathscr O(X,t_1)O(X,t1​) and O(X,t2)\mathscr O(X,t_2)O(X,t2​) (categories of open subsets) goes in the other direction.
I think the natural convention for Grothendieck topologies is that T <= S implies that “being a T-sheaf implies being an S-sheaf”.
Is that what it’s like in mathlib?
It's the opposite. The mathlib version is instead consistent with stacks: https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/00ZQ, and with the elephant. See also https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/00YZ
Finally I see the symbol ≤ being used (in stacks#00YZ)! @Patrick Massot was complaining ⊆ is not the same symbol.
I don't think the stacks link goes against Patrick's argument, this is the ≤ symbol being used for sieves, not for topologies on a space
